In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Transformational Mobile Banking Services policy and advisory technical assistance 
(TA) project will make possible the creation of an informed and effective regulatory environment 
that fosters the expansion of, and competition and innovation in, mobile phone-based banking 
services (“m-banking”) for the underbanked in Mongolia. A fact-finding mission visited Mongolia 
on  14–17  February  2009  and  the  Government  confirmed  the  TA’s  objectives,  scope,  and 
implementation arrangements.1 The project's design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.    “Branchless banking” is an umbrella term for the process by which a customer may 
perform banking transactions electronically without visiting an actual bank. Electronic banking 
(“e-banking”) involves the remote delivery of new and traditional banking products and services 
through electronic delivery channels such as the internet. M-banking is a subset of e-banking, 
and  involves  the  use  of  a  mobile  phone  or  other  mobile  devices  to  undertake  financial 
transactions linked to a client’s account, which may or may not exist in a bank. M-banking 
services  are  simple,  typically  requiring  only  that  the  client  understands  how  to  send  text 
messages to transmit or receive account information or make payments. These services are 
some of the most rapidly growing initiatives in developing countries, enabled by (i) the rapid 
growth of mobile phone coverage and ownership; and (ii) the fact that cheaper mobile devices, 
which enable remote transactions, may have more effective outreach than physical branches.2 
 
3.  A substantial body of evidence demonstrates that improving access to financial services 
helps poor people and decreases poverty, and that technological improvements are a key part 
of this process. Beck et al showed that the highest barriers to financial services for the poor are 
physical access to bank services. 3 The Financial Sector Development, Economic Growth, and 
Poverty Reduction: A Literature Review of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) notes that 
financial sector development alleviates poverty by increasing access, and that development 
assistance  has  been  helpful  in  improving  regulatory  environments  and  can  have  catalytic 
effects.4 m- Banking: A Knowledge Map cites both theoretical and practical evidence that m-
banking  will  expand  access  to  financial  services  for  large  numbers  of  poor  and  isolated 
households.5 The study notes further that donors have done little to explore the transformational 
potential  of  mobile  banking,  and  recommends  that  donors  support  improvements  in  the 
informational, policy and regulatory environment for m-banking.  
 
4.  The Enabling Environment for Mobile Banking in Africa defines two regulatory models for 
m-banking:6  (i)  the  additive  model,  in  which  a  mobile  phone  is  an  additional  method—
complementing computers—to access banking or other financial services, and is suitable for 
middle-income households; and (ii) a transformational model, in which the mobile phone is used

2 
as a basis for expanding initial access to financial services, particularly for poor, rural and more 
isolated households that would otherwise not have access to such financial services. The 
transformational model has vast potential but has only taken hold in about six countries, all of 
which have relatively open regulatory regimes. In the last 3 years, millions of m-banking clients 
have accessed formal financial services, many for the first time, in Brazil, Jordan, Kenya, 
Maldives, the Philippines, and South Africa. In the Philippines, which is the key model for 
transformational m-banking, both large mobile telephone operators have partnered with banks 
to provide clients with domestic and international remittances, payments services, and even 
rural salary payments without the need for a bank account or a physical branch.  
 
5.  The transformational model is more suited for countries and regions wishing to expand 
their financial services geographically and to deepen financial markets. There are three criteria: 
(i) widespread access to mobile phones, (ii) a wider pool of informed and literate potential 
customers, and (iii) the existence of an actual or potential system of payments that allows for 
cash withdrawals (and the potential to expand to agent arrangements). All of these conditions 
exist  in  Mongolia.  Currently,  there  are  four  cell  phone  providers  and  34  internet  service 
providers in the market. Costs have decreased for users and coverage has increased. As of 
2008, cell phone users number 1.7 million and subscribed Internet users total 110,000.7 The 
primary persons who need improved access to financial services are herders, civil servants, 
small business people, and pensioners. The population of 2.8 million is highly literate (over 
95 %) and the median age is 25. However, a total of 36.1% of Mongolians live below the poverty 
line of $0.75 per day (with half living under $2.00 per day). The rural population of approximately 
1.6 million is scattered, isolated and highly mobile. Half of the people who live in the rural areas 
are semi-nomadic herders who may only visit an area with physical banking services twice a 
year, although they are very likely to have cell phone access and to make regular stops in small 
village areas for provisions and social reasons.  Regular trade even in the smallest areas and a 
good payments system allows the third condition to be met.  
 
6.  Banks constitute an estimated 95% of the formal financial system in Mongolia, with three 
banks dominating 70% of the market. The banks which have demonstrated the most interest in 
reaching rural areas are Xaan Bank, Mongol Post Bank, and Xac Bank. Margins are quite high 
(up to 20% per annum) consistent with the costs of maintaining networks outside the capital and 
other market weaknesses. Bank savings services have grown rapidly in rural areas, as have 
selected forms of collateral-based credit and minor unsecured microcredit. While a significant 
development has been the increase in accessible microfinance, the numbers are still quite small. 
In 2001, less than 1% of the population had access to lending from mainstream financial 
institutions, and this number grew to 15% by 2005.  
 
7.  Recent  sector  review  work  suggests  that  the  government  should  encourage  the 
development of new products and services which can support the development of micro-, small-, 
and medium-sized enterprises, particularly in rural areas. Mongolia's uniquely low population 
density  makes  traditional  branch  systems  prohibitively  expensive,  so  m-banking  is  a  very 
realistic alternative to increase access to finance. And with costs of brick-and-mortar branches 
rising, it is critical to introduce methods for lowering the costs of providing financial services in 
rural areas—which m-banking can accomplish.

8.  A recent rapid review of mobile banking regulation in Mongolia found that while the 
environment was not explicitly resistive, lack of clarity has prevented transformational mobile 
banking from developing.8 Banks are regulated by the Bank of Mongolia (BOM), the country’s 
central bank. Nonbank entities that plan to offer financial services have to obtain a license from 
the  Financial  Regulatory  Commission.  The  Communication  Regulatory  Commission  is  the 
actual regulator in this space, while the Information, Communication Technology, and Post 
Agency is ostensibly the policy maker. These two organizations develop laws and regulations 
for e-commerce, e-security, and e-signatures. Lack of clarity creates confusion regarding the 
roles of BOM and the Financial Regulatory Commission as well as those for the Communication 
Regulatory Commission and the Information, Communication Technology, and Post Agency in 
mobile banking.  
  
9.  Within the current regulatory framework, laws do not restrict banks or licensed nonbank 
financial  institutions  from  providing  a  range  of  mobile  financial  services.  Currently,  the  m-
banking  services  that  are  available  for  individual  users  in  Mongolia  include  account 
management, bill payment, loan monitoring, and credit card management.9 However, these 
services are available only to a small number of wealthy urban clients. M-banking services are 
not offered to poorer households. Regulators have not yet considered the potential of this 
technology to deepen financial services to poorer households or as a mechanism to improve 
trade. At the same time, there is no legal structure describing oversight of agencies, e-security, 
consumer  protection,  and  a  number  of  other  relevant  issues.  There  are  no  definitions  of 
payment, e-money, e-money services, card-based instruments or other important distinctions. 
Although there is some awareness of mobile banking where the mobile services are tied to a 
bank account, there is little understanding of stored value services that create virtual accounts 
on either cards, mobile phones, or other devices. This latter concept is not only absent from the 
laws, it is not part of the thinking of many potential players in the market.  
 
10.  While the private sector is interested in m-banking, it is unlikely that transformational m-
banking will be introduced and targeted to the poor without appropriate market information, 
regulation, and potential subsidy for the first pilots. Such arrangements will define the difference 
between additive and transformational m-banking development. In Mongolia, the BOM has the 
responsibility  of  establishing  rules  for  m-banking.  Xac  Bank  has  proposed  the  piloting  of 
transformational m-banking services, and a small grant for startup has been provided by the 
Consultative Group to Assist the Poor. However, regulations have not yet been established and 
consistently promulgated across regulators, preventing Xac Bank from starting their pilot.  
 
11.  ADB became involved in mobile banking relatively recently, and the work undertaken 
has been comprised primarily of assessments of the enabling environment in the Pacific and 
Pakistan.10 Situational studies were completed in Vanuatu, Papua New Guinea, and Tonga in 
2008 under regional TA projects, with additional work being contemplated. In September 2008, 
a study on improving access to financial services in Pakistan through the use of technology was 
conducted, which suggested the provision of subsidies to expand branchless banking services 
to unbanked areas, based on a review of conditions and the existing Branchless Banking 
Regulation.11

A key study on the impact of m-banking on AML was completed by ADB in 2008.12 However, 
none of the work to date has provided for a standard methodology for regulation, supervision, 
and market development. In addition, none of the work has provided specific attention to cross-
border remittances, which are a major feature in m-banking internationally.  
 
12.  The Mongolia Country Program Strategy 2006-2008 includes as the financial sector 
outcome "sound financial system with improved efficiency and outreach and improved access to 
financial services."13 The 2008-2010 Mongolia Country Operational Business Plan14 states that 
advisory TA is expected to address institutional strengthening and efficiency of public service 
delivery, and that efforts will be made to supplement the non-lending program with co-financing. 
The  proposed  R-PATA  will  enable  the  implementation  of  a  regulatory  system  for  mobile 
telephone-based financial services which will facilitate both competition and transformational 
market behavior to expand financial services to poorer households, particularly in rural areas. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact of this TA will be improved access to formal financial services among the 
poor and unbanked in Mongolia through the introduction of transformational mobile banking 
services. Its outcome will be a regulatory environment for m-banking that promotes competitive, 
transformational  market  behaviors.  Measurable  results  expected  by  the  end  of  the  TA’s 
implementation  include  m-banking  interoperability  and  consistent  regulatory  agreements 
between key regulators in Mongolia, m-banking financial regulations that meet emergent good 
practice, and at least one pilot transformational m-banking startup by end 2012.  
 
14.  The TA will build on recent experience and market conditions to enable an informed 
regulatory environment that fosters the expansion of, and competition and innovation in, m-
banking.  Implementation  will  include  an  m-banking  oversight  committee  made  up  of  key 
regulators in finance and telecommunications; a diagnostic structure for the market to review 
and identify key gaps and hindrances to the operation and expansion of transformational m-
banking services; a statement of intent, guidelines on essential policy, and facilitated regulatory 
reform for m-banking to ensure the implementation of appropriate rules.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  First, the consultants will review existing m-banking studies to determine methodologies, 
and extract insights that can be used for the TA’s purposes. They will identify methods for 
identifying and engaging all potential regulatory bodies and other key players, and recommend 
a methodology for the review of the regulatory environment and structures relevant to m-
banking.  Aspects  of  m-banking  which  may  influence  its  transformational  nature  and/or  its 
influence  across  borders  will  be  identified  and  incorporated  into  the  methodology.  The 
diagnostic tool for branchless banking developed by the Consultative Group to Assist the Poor 
will also be considered.15 The methodology will then be finalized.

16.  Next, a joint m-banking oversight committee with private sector representation will be 
established. The committee will include members who represent regulators for banks, other 
types of financial institutions, telephony, competition, and consumer protection as appropriate. A 
diagnostic review of current regulatory framework will then be undertaken, focusing on the 
enabling  principles,  the  gaps  and  hindrances  to  the  development  of  m-banking,  and  the 
consequences of regulatory weaknesses. An international study tour to the Philippines will be 
provided to assist regulators to see a successful and appropriate regulatory framework. Based 
on the results of this analysis, a statement of intent and a policy road map for the reform of 
regulations  will  be  drafted  and  endorsed  The  reforms  in  Mongolia's  road  map  will  be 
implemented  under  the  m-banking  oversight  committee  and  the  first  pilot  approved  for 
implementation. At three key points, workshops will disseminate findings to stakeholders. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.   The TA is estimated to cost $450,000 equivalent, of which $400,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF—Others). Contributions by 
the Government of Mongolia, estimated at $50,000 equivalent on an in-kind basis, will cover 
remuneration of counterpart staff, office space and meeting venues, furniture, administrative 
support, and logistics. The TA will cover remuneration, travel, and per diem of consultants, as 
well  as  training,  workshops,  publications,  and  miscellaneous  expenses.  The  detailed  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented for 18 months, from 31 January 2010 to 31 July 2011. The 
BOM will be the executing agency, with guidance from the m-banking oversight committee. ADB 
will consult broadly for the development of the standard methodology for m-banking use.  
 
19.  One  international  consultant  (for  a  total  of  7  person-months)  and  two  national 
consultants (for 20 person-months), with expertise in the areas of mobile banking regulation, 
telephone regulation, and regulatory facilitation, will be individually recruited and engaged by 
ADB, in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time 
to time). The consultants' terms of reference are in Appendix 3. Individual consultant recruitment 
is justified by (i) the need for expediency; and (ii) simplicity of the recruitment requirements.  
 
20.  Equipment for use by the m-banking committee and TA consultants (two computers and 
software, a high-speed internet connection, a printer and a photocopier) will be procured by 
ADB in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time), 
and will be handed over at the end of the TA to the BOM. Seminars, overseas tours, and 
conferences will be included in the contract of, and will be organized and administered by, the 
international consultant. TA proceeds will be disbursed in line with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook.16 
    
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
 
the Government of Mongolia for Transformational Mobile Banking Services, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consultants, one international (7 person-months) and two national consultants (20 
person-months), will be individually selected and engaged by the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time) and arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of national consultants. 
Equipment (two computers and software, a high-speed internet connection, a printer and a 
photocopier for use by the m-banking committee and the technical assistance [TA] consultants) 
will be procured by each  implementing agency, as appropriate, in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). The international consultant will 
work according to his/her terms of reference and will provide data on possible learning and 
synergies; he/she will report to the ADB project officer in close collaboration with the Bank of 
Mongolia  and  consult  frequently  with  the  m-banking  oversight  committee.  The  national 
consultants will report to the international consultant acting as the team leader and, in the 
latter’s absence, to the chair of the country oversight committee. Consultants will be required to 
provide deliverables consistent with the design and monitoring framework activities, outputs, 
and delivery dates; reports are to be of high quality and produced in English, with copies in 
Mongolian (as appropriate) by the report delivery dates.

A.  International Consultant 
1.  Mobile Banking Lead Specialist and Team Leader (international, 7 person-
months, intermittent)  
2.  Qualifications. The m-banking expert will have at least a master’s degree in economics, 
business administration, law, information technology, engineering, or a similar field. The expert 
will have at least 7 years of experience in information technology, regulatory assessments, and 
advisory services for national financial regulators, with at least 4 years of work on m-banking 
regulation, supervision, and environments. He or she will preferably have experience in the 
rollout of m-banking service programs. The expert will be an excellent communicator. Prior 
experience with Asian, and particularly with Mongolian officials on financial sector issues will be 
helpful, as will relevant language expertise. 
 
3.  Tasks. The consultant will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  lead all consultants in the timely and effective completion of the TA outputs and 
results; 
(ii)  lead and be responsible for the development and finalization of a standardized 
methodology for m-banking market and regulatory review, which incorporates 
key aspects of transformational m-banking; consult with Mongolian regulators on 
the viability of the methodology; and revise said methodology accordingly; and 
modify next steps depending on the results of this step; 
(iii)  support the establishment of an m-banking oversight committee in Mongolia, 
including (a) providing advice on suitable membership and terms of reference for 
the committee, and (b) establishing support for committee operations; 
(iv)  arrange  and  administer  all  study  tours,  with  the  support  of  the  national 
consultants; 
(v)  with  the  consultant  team  and  consistent  with  the  methodology,  undertake  a 
diagnostic review of the current regulatory and market situation and support the 
m-banking oversight committee in reviewing and revising a final review document; 
(vi)  working with the central banks, consultants, and the m-banking committee, help 
develop a statement of intent and policy roadmap for regulatory system reform in 
Mongolia to enable interoperability and other standards to be met; 
(vii)  support the m-banking oversight committee in undertaking the first key reforms in 
the road map of Mongolia; and  
(viii)  facilitate  the  dissemination  of  information  to  relevant  stakeholders  by  the 
implementing agency to ensure they understand the products, issues, risks, and 
benefits.

specializing in financial sector issues. He/she will have at least 5 years of experience handling 
the review of financial sector regulations, particularly the introduction of new technology, and will 
have particular familiarity with developments in the banking system in Mongolia. The specialist 
will have access to suitable documents, regulatory information, and findings to help ensure the 
completion of TA outputs, and have clear knowledge of and contacts within the current structure 
and operations of financial regulators. The specialist will be have strong English language skills,
